xsi:type="CoverageType"><northBoundLatitude>32.03</northBoundLatitude><westBoundLongitude>-79.0</westBoundLongitude><southBoundLatitude>26.85</southBoundLatitude><eastBoundLongitude>-75.69</eastBoundLongitude></dc:coverage><linkage type="metadata">https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.747054</linkage><linkage type="data">https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.747054?format=textfile</linkage><additionalContent>Ship: Scorpion (Sloop), Start of voyage: 1750-07-12, End of voyage: 1750-07-23, Voyage: Brunswick - Cape Fear, 1st Observer: John Randell (Captain), 2nd Observer: Littleton Hill (1st Officer/Master), Company: Royal Navy, Other ship information: 10G 268BM</additionalContent><additionalContent>Wind direction (from which the wind is blowing) in whole degrees from: 1-360; 361 = calm, 362 = variable. It is not clear from many logbook entries whether the wind direction has been corrected for the magnetic variation (or declination). To avoid any misunderstanding, all winds from reports that included a valid position in the period 1750-1854 were corrected. All other wind directions are given without being corrected.</additionalContent><additionalContent>calculated from the descriptive terms of wind force given in the observations</additionalContent><additionalContent>Name of first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>Bearing of the first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>Distance to the first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If position is considered to be coastal (in port or near coastal disturbances)</additionalContent><additionalContent>Course of the ship during the past 24 hours</additionalContent><additionalContent>Distance travelled during the previous 24 hours</additionalContent><additionalContent>It is generally accepted by the CLIWOC team that the wind directions, reported by the ships officers, were relative to the magnetic North direction. Navigators were well aware of the difference between the true and magnetic north direction, but the compasses (we assumed that the bearing-compasses were mostly used for determining the wind direction) were not always adjusted. Therefore the wind direction has to be corrected. The magnetic declination (or variation, as it is known on board ships) is given for the whole CLIWOC period (1750-1850) for every 5x5 degree square. The number was added to the wind direction to get the true wind direction.</additionalContent><additionalContent>All reported wind directions on this day. The wind direction is the direction that points to where the wind comes from.</additionalContent><additionalContent>All reported wind forces on this day</additionalContent><additionalContent>Weather description</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If wind gusts are reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If rain was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If fog was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If snow was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If thunder and or lightning was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If hail was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If sea-ice or icebergs were reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>CLIWOC 2.1 line number</additionalContent></dataset>

xsi:type="CoverageType"><northBoundLatitude>34.2</northBoundLatitude><westBoundLongitude>-78.32999999999998</westBoundLongitude><southBoundLatitude>33.449999999999996</southBoundLatitude><eastBoundLongitude>-76.0</eastBoundLongitude></dc:coverage><linkage type="metadata">https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.747056</linkage><linkage type="data">https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.747056?format=textfile</linkage><additionalContent>Ship: Scorpion (Sloop), Start of voyage: 1750-11-15, End of voyage: 1750-11-19, Voyage: Ocracoke - Southport, 1st Observer: John Russell (Captain), 2nd Observer: Littleton Hill (2nd Officer/Lieutenant), Company: Royal Navy, Other ship information: 10G 268BM</additionalContent><additionalContent>Wind direction (from which the wind is blowing) in whole degrees from: 1-360; 361 = calm, 362 = variable. It is not clear from many logbook entries whether the wind direction has been corrected for the magnetic variation (or declination). To avoid any misunderstanding, all winds from reports that included a valid position in the period 1750-1854 were corrected. All other wind directions are given without being corrected.</additionalContent><additionalContent>calculated from the descriptive terms of wind force given in the observations</additionalContent><additionalContent>Name of first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>Bearing of the first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>Distance to the first landmark</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If position is considered to be coastal (in port or near coastal disturbances)</additionalContent><additionalContent>Course of the ship during the past 24 hours</additionalContent><additionalContent>Distance travelled during the previous 24 hours</additionalContent><additionalContent>Other remarks, that were not possible to put in the other remark fields</additionalContent><additionalContent>It is generally accepted by the CLIWOC team that the wind directions, reported by the ships officers, were relative to the magnetic North direction. Navigators were well aware of the difference between the true and magnetic north direction, but the compasses (we assumed that the bearing-compasses were mostly used for determining the wind direction) were not always adjusted. Therefore the wind direction has to be corrected. The magnetic declination (or variation, as it is known on board ships) is given for the whole CLIWOC period (1750-1850) for every 5x5 degree square. The number was added to the wind direction to get the true wind direction.</additionalContent><additionalContent>All reported wind directions on this day. The wind direction is the direction that points to where the wind comes from.</additionalContent><additionalContent>All reported wind forces on this day</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If wind gusts are reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If rain was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If fog was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If snow was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If thunder and or lightning was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If hail was reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>1 If sea-ice or icebergs were reported</additionalContent><additionalContent>CLIWOC 2.1 line number</additionalContent></dataset>
